awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Expansion/Contraction of the Intertropical Convergence Zone; An Emerging Mechanism of Tropical Precipitation Changes for Reinterpreting Paleoclimate
awd_abstract_narration:
The spatial distribution of tropical precipitation is determined by the average location and seasonal march of the intertropical convergence zone (ITCZ). The latitudinal shift of the ITCZ is typically employed as the go-to theory for interpreting past hydroclimate changes and defining mechanisms of the response to climate forcing (past and future). 

This project, however, is based on the premise that the simultaneous contraction and intensification (CI) of the ITCZ is a far more powerful mode of tropical precipitation changes (by a factor of 4) in response to both paleoclimate and anthropogenic forcing than the more commonly employed ITCZ shift.

The overarching goal of the project is to couple reconstructions of past changes in the CI mode from paleoclimate proxy records with a dynamical framework of the CI mode to constrain future tropical precipitation changes and variability. This specific aims are to: i) explore the dynamics of the CI mode to identify the mechanisms that lead to the direction of changes seen in simulations of past and future climate as well as evaluate the uncertainties in these processes and ii) use the emerging knowledge of the CI mode to reinterpret the paleoclimate record to constrain the past behavior of ITCZ shifts versus CI. 

The project would help develop a deeper understanding of the ITCZ and potentially improve the ability of climate models to forecast broad-scale future changes (and variability) in the magnitude and spatial structure topical precipitation.  The project would also support two early career scientists and leverage existing public outreach programs in science at the University of Washington and the University of California-Berkeley.

por.por_cntn:
Our understanding of past climate change from compilations of sparsely located paleoclimate proxy data inherently relies on assumptions about the dominant modes (i.e. spatial patterns) of climate variability and change. For example, concurrent increases in precipitation in one latitude band and decreases in a different latitude band have frequently been interpreted in terms of a latitudinal shift of the region of intense tropical precipitation – the intertropical convergence zone (ITCZ). This ITCZ shift paradigm has dominated the literature on past and future changes in tropical precipitation. Our work demonstrates that ITCZ shifts explain a very small fraction of simulated changes in tropical precipitation in a large ensemble of model simulations under paleoclimate and anthropogenic forcing.  Instead, the dominant mode of simulated tropical precipitation change is a simultaneous latitudinal contraction (i.e. squeezing in toward the equator) and intensification under global warming and a latitudinal expansion and reduction under global cooling. This mode of tropical precipitation change – which we term the contraction/intensification (CI) mode—explains over 50% of the simulated changes in the latitudinal structure (averaged across all longitudes) in response to Last Glacial Maximum boundary conditions, freshwater forcing of the North Atlantic, Mid-Holocene boundary conditions, volcanic events, and increases in atmospheric carbon dioxide. In contrast, the commonly invoked ITCZ shift explains less than 10% of the spatial pattern of tropical precipitation changes in the same ensemble of simulations. Our results suggest that the CI mode is a far more powerful mode of tropical precipitation changes than the ITCZ shift and that knowledge of the CI mode should be used to reinterpret the paleoclimate record.

              What mechanism accounts for the latitudinal contraction of tropical precipitation under global warming?  We demonstrated that the contraction results from a reduced seasonal migration of the ITCZ off the equator under global warming. In colder climates the ITCZ migrates farther off the equator into the summer hemisphere during the solstice season resulting in a latitudinal smearing out of the precipitation in the annual mean; whereas in warmer climates this seasonal migration of the ITCZ is reduced resulting in precipitation that is more confined to near the equator in the annual mean. What then controls the latitudinal extent of the seasonal migration of the ITCZ off the equator? We developed a theory which states that the seasonal migration of the ITCZ off the equator is directly proportional to the seasonal heating of the atmosphere and indirectly proportional to the efficiency of atmospheric energy transport from one hemisphere to the other. The reduced seasonal migration of the ITCZ under global warming is due to a robust increase in the efficiency of cross equatorial energy transport which we speculate results from tropopause rising and enhanced eddy moisture transport. The same theory was used to demonstrate that climate models have an overly expansive tropical mean state as compared to observations – the so called double ITCZ bias -- due to excessive seasonal migration of the ITCZ. The latter results from exaggerated seasonal heating of the atmosphere.

              We then focused our attention on the longitudinal structure of tropical precipitation changes under paleoclimate and anthropogenic forcing. We found that the longitudinal variations in the forced tropical precipitation response generally exceeded the latitudinal variations (averaged across all longitudes). This result suggested that sparsely located proxy date likely provide little information about latitudinal shifts and contractions of the ITCZ. However, in many cases robust longitudinal patterns of tropical precipitation changes specific to region and forcing type were found. This result suggested that regional mechanism of forced climate change should be further studied and may provide insight to interpreting the dynamics underlying sparsely located paleoclimate proxy records.
